Program 2 Risk Management Plan

Helena Ruth Grant Pad

Facility ID: 100000233865

WPX Energy, Inc.



3.0  EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



3.1  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Stationary Source

It is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws.  If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to notify the Three Tribes Fire Management and request that they respond to the emergency. 



3.2  Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

BFX Midstream, LLC (BFX) owns and operates a portable refrigeration type gas dew point control and liquids recovery skid designed to recover hydrocarbon liquids from produced gas prior to gathering and final treatment for WPX Energy, Inc. (WPX) at the Helena Ruth Grant Pad. The system is designed to remove liquids from gas at the wellhead.  The refrigeration system can operate at subzero temperatures.  BFX uses this system to remove liquids from produced gas prior to flaring. Four LPG portable storage tanks will be used for liquid products storage. Each has a maximum capacity of 18,000 gallons. BFX limits the maximum fill to 80% of the tank volume or 14,400 gallons each which is equivalent 82,224 lbs. of flammable liquids. The worst case scenario would be that all the tanks exploded and the total pounds of flammable liquids used for the analysis is 328,896 lbs. 



3.3  Worst-Case Release Scenario(s) and the Alternative Release Scenario(s)

The LPG storage tanks are the largest process at 14,400 gallons each. Should a spill occur, all of 57,600 gallons from the four tanks of LPG is assumed to be released in the worst-case release scenario.  Per 40 CFR 68.25 (1), for regulated flammable gases handled as liquids under pressure the total quantity in the vessel is assumed to be released as a gas over a 10-minute period resulting in a vapor cloud explosion. The resulting distance to the endpoint extends offsite, and public receptors are within the distance to the

endpoint. The alternative release scenario is a break in the piping system that flows to the LPG storage tanks resulting in a release of 106 gallons of flammable liquid. The resulting vapor cloud explosion has no receptors within the distance to the endpoint.



3.4  General Accidental Release Prevention Program

"It is the policy of WPX and BFX at the Helena Ruth Grant Pad to:

?    Comply with all applicable safety, health, and environment laws and regulations;

?    Ensure that all unsafe conditions are properly identified and reported, and promptly corrected;

?    Provide training to all personnel so that they can consistently and safely perform their duties; and

?    Maintain a safe workplace through prevention, detection, and mitigation."



The BFX gas plant complies with EPA's accident prevention rule applicable state and local codes and regulations.  The system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with ASTM standards.



3.4.1  Management System



WPX and BFX have developed a simplified management system to plan, organize, implement and control the risk management program elements. The management system activities are further discussed below.



?    Planning - The HRG Pad has an overall risk management program policy that clearly identifies the goals and objectives of the risk management program.



?    Organizing - BFX is responsible for ensuring that written procedures for each risk management program element are developed to meet identified goals and objectives. BFX and their operators hold meetings for the purpose of integrating and coordinating each risk management program element.



?    Implementing - BFX provides training to all operators regarding initiating the process elements, implementing the process elements, and documenting the elements during the meetings. Personnel are provided with initial training on the applicable risk management procedures. Refresher training is provided on an as-needed basis but is conducted at a minimum following an

y changes to the program elements or following reauthorization.



?    Controlling - WPX is responsible for conducting internal reviews or audits of each risk management program element against the goals and objectives of the element. 



3.4.2  Prevention Program Elements

The prevention programs described in the RMP represent integrated administrative controls intended to ensure the safety of workers, the public, and the environment. Based on the design hazard review applicable safeguards that have already been implemented. These safeguards prevent, detect, or mitigate accidental releases of flammable liquid.

?    Safety Information

Safety information has been included in the RMP

?    Hazard Review

A Process Hazard Analysis was conducted of the gas plant design prior to building the plant.

?    Operating Procedures

Operating procedures are established for the safe operation of the gas plant.

?    Training

Operators of the plant are provided on the job training. The operators' competency is tested by demonstration of the correct procedures and understanding of the process.

?    Maintenance

Maintenance checklists are utilized and documented.

?    Compliance Audit

No compliance audits are currently scheduled for the gas plant.

?    Incident Investigation

There have been no incidences to investigate.



3.5  Five-Year Accident History

There has never been an accident involving flammable liquids that caused deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place.



3.6  Emergency Response Program

In the event of an emergency involving the BFX gas plant, it is our policy to notify the TAT Fire Department and request that they respond to the emergency. We have coordinated our response plans with the fire departments listed in the emergency response plan; members of the fire department have inspected our pads, and we have conducted exercises with them.



3.7  Planned Changes to Improve Safety

BFX Midstream has implemented the necessary changes

in the design based on a Process Hazard Analysis. There are no currently planned changes to improve safety. The process and equipment will be constantly observed during operations for changes that are needed to improve safety.
